repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
- Move all generator Lua scripts to the `src/gen/`
- Add a `.luarc.json` to `src/gen/`
- Add a `preload.lua` to `src/gen/`
  - Add `src` to `package.path` so it aligns with `.luarc.json'
- Fix all `require` statements in `src/gen/` so they are consistent:
    - `require('scripts.foo')` -> `require('gen.foo')`
    - `require('src.nvim.options')` -> `require('nvim.options')`
    - `require('api.dispatch_deprecated')` -> `require('nvim.api.dispatch_deprecated')`

comment_data.body: Should this file stay here or move to `src/gen` as it depends on a file in `src/gen`.

This file, and a few others like `lintcommit.lua`, `genappimage.sh`, `check_urls.vim`, and maybe `bump_deps.lua`, are "build tasks". It could be an improvement to introduce a top-level "build/ci tasks" dir, but OTOH maybe `scripts/` already is serving that purpose.

Note that "generators" are a big topic so even if `scripts/` is defined as "build tasks", I think `src/gen/` or `build.gen/` is justified.
Should it stay or should it move?
This is primarily a build task, not a generator, so scripts/ is currently the best place for it.

comment_regular_data.body:
>  Move all generator Lua scripts to the `scripts/`

Why? These scripts are part of the build, and the source.

The scripts/ dir is a hack, not intended to grow into this increasingly important role. It's more like a place for things that haven't found a proper place, yet.

>  It's more like a place for things that haven't found a proper place, yet.

Then we need to find that place, and/or prune the non-essential scripts. Right now, essential (Lua) scripts are spread out over multiple directories, which makes linting and type checking harder.

I suggest putting these either in a top-level `build.gen/` dir, or `src/gen/` dir.

> which makes linting and type checking harder.

Why would lint/type-checking treat these scripts any differently than other Lua files?
Works for me, but then the generator scripts from `scripts/` need to be moved there (and our pipelines adapted) so that `scripts` only contains one-off chaff and can be ignored by lintlua.

> so that `scripts` only contains one-off chaff and can be ignored by lintlua.

Why don't we want lintlua to check all Lua code?
Shouldn't `src` include source code, not multi-use miscellaneous Lua scripts/modules. Why isn't `runtime` in `src`? Especially as we have files in there which are embedded into the Nvim binary.

> I suggest putting these either in a top-level build.gen/ dir, or src/gen/ dir.

Done

> Why would lint/type-checking treat these scripts any differently than other Lua files?

LuaLS needs to properly understand the directory layout. Our scripts were not preloaded consistently which meant the `require` statements were not consistent. I've now fixed that. E.g. `c_grammar.lua` is always required as `require('gen.c_grammar')`.

> Shouldn't `src` include source code, not multi-use miscellaneous Lua scripts/modules.

Build scripts are not multi-use misc scripts.

> Why isn't `runtime` in `src`?

Open to improvement, but the answers currently are:

- Vim legacy: runtime/ is for non-compiled stuff that is shipped to the user but not part of the core `nvim` binary.
- Nvim legacy: we have some "binary" `nvim` Lua modules in `runtime/lua` because separating them would be even more confusing.

Some careful thought could improve that, but it's orthogonal to the immediate topic of build/generator scripts.

`scripts/` now just contains:

```
bump_deps.lua   cliff.toml                 genappimage.sh  lintdoc.lua  shadacat.py         vim-patch.sh  windows.ti
check_urls.vim  download-unicode-files.sh  lintcommit.lua  release.sh   update_terminfo.sh  vimpatch.lua
```

> Build scripts are not multi-use misc scripts.

`c_grammar.lua` is not a build script, it is multi-use.

> `c_grammar.lua` is not a build script, it is multi-use.

It could make sense to ship that to users, so it may eventually find its way into `runtime/`. But yeah, `scripts/` (or a ["build tasks" dir](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32638#discussion_r1971500266)) is a place for things like that which aren't ready to be shipped yet.

> It could make sense to ship that to users,

I'd strongly advise against that. It's not a general C grammar, very (very) far from it. It just parses enough C patterns (with support for _our_ preproc macros) for our purposes of building docs and other C code. Shipping it to users would provide unnecessary API burden, and we will lose flexibility to change it, same goes for our other Lpeg grammars.

> But yeah, scripts/ (or a https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32638#discussion_r1971500266) is a place for things like that which aren't ready to be shipped yet.

This is initially why I grouped everything into `scripts`, however since you are against that, and since we need `c_grammar` to builds docs and the Nvim binary, I've placed it in `src/gen`, the same workspace as all other files that use it.

The way I want to structure this, is that we have a single internal Lua project directory (named whatever (idc), currently `src/gen`) that handles all this stuff (build, doc, linting, etc), rather than modules pulling other modules from various random places. This would give use 3 distinct Lua projects within our codebase:
- `runtime`
- `test`
- `src/gen`

Any scripts we create goes in one of these three projects and preloaded accordingly.

> The way I want to structure this, is that we have a single internal Lua project directory (named whatever (idc), currently `src/gen`) that handles all this stuff (build, doc, linting, etc), rather than modules pulling other modules from various random places.

Defining the goal like that is rather narrow. The generator scripts are quite unrelated to lint tasks, and random stuff like `bump_deps.lua`.

> rather than modules pulling other modules from various random places

Dependencies are dependencies. If a lint task in `scripts/` uses a lua module that happens to live in `src/gen/`, why is that a problem?

> `scripts/` now just contains:
> 
> ```
> bump_deps.lua   cliff.toml                 genappimage.sh  lintdoc.lua  shadacat.py         vim-patch.sh  windows.ti
> check_urls.vim  download-unicode-files.sh  lintcommit.lua  release.sh   update_terminfo.sh  vimpatch.lua
> ```

`lintcommit.lua` could be moved to `.github/scripts` (or is anybody running this locally?)

> (or is anybody running this locally?)

Pretend that they do. Because in general, build tasks need to live somewhere, and putting them in multiple places increases confusion.

One long-term solution is to create a `test/lint/` place where lint tasks can live.

> Defining the goal like that is rather narrow. The generator scripts are quite unrelated to lint tasks.

I disagree, `gcc` is a linter and a generator, `rust` and `zig` are certainly linters, and I generally always consider linting as part of the build phase. The same goes for documentation.

> Dependencies are dependencies. If a lint task in scripts/ uses a lua module that happens to live in src/gen/, why is that a problem?

Lua tooling, which we are increasingly dependent on to help validate our code. If everything is spread out, it makes it more difficult to manage (#32582), and things rot quicker because of reduced locality.

I've seen this problem manifest in other projects which have python scripts dotted about the codebase, whereas python's tooling works best when there is a dedicated python package, at least when dependencies are involved. This is because these files all need to be launched in an environment, and if the files are too scattered, it makes having a consistent launcher much more difficult to manage.

With this change, the 3 `.luarc`'s now roughly align with the 3/4 preload scripts we have, which means there is now exactly 4 different execution environments for any Lua code that is run in this repo.

1). `nlua` in `src/gen/`: Used by most of the generator scripts to build the Nvim binary.
2). `nvim_lua` in `src/gen/`: Used by `gen_vimdoc`, `gen_eval_files` and `lintdoc`
3). `nvim` busted in `test/`
4). `nvim` runtime in `runtime/`

1). and 2). now share the same Lua package (and `.luarc`) with similar preloaders. Main difference is `nlua` doesn't have `vim.uv` or `VIMRUNTIME`

These could be split into `src/gen` and `doc`, but then we'd need a common package for files like `c_grammar.lua` etc. Seems much more pragmatic to just group these.
That is a useful summary/framing, mind putting it in an issue and we can continue discussion there?

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: building and installing Neovim using the provided scripts
labels.name: build

title: build: move all generator scripts to `src/gen/`
